title: Application Layer
description: Understanding application layer protocols, services, and client-server architecture

keyConcepts.title: Application Layer Position
keyConcepts.description: Top layer of TCP/IP model (Layer 4), closest to the end user. Provides network services directly to applications like web browsers, email clients, and file transfer programs.

keyConcepts.title: Client-Server Model
keyConcepts.description: Client initiates requests for services; server provides those services. Examples: web browser (client) requests pages from web server, email client retrieves mail from email server.

keyConcepts.title: DNS (Domain Name System)
keyConcepts.description: Resolves human-readable domain names (www.cisco.com) to IP addresses. Uses hierarchical structure: root servers, TLD (.com, .org), authoritative name servers.

keyConcepts.title: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)
keyConcepts.description: Automates IP address assignment to network devices. Provides IP address, subnet mask, default gateway, and DNS server information. Essential for large networks.

keyConcepts.title: HTTP/HTTPS
keyConcepts.description: HTTP transfers web content using GET (retrieve), POST (submit data), PUT (upload). HTTPS adds SSL/TLS encryption for secure communication.

keyConcepts.title: Email Protocols
keyConcepts.description: SMTP sends email from client to server or between servers. POP3 downloads email to client (usually deletes from server). IMAP keeps email on server with synchronization across devices.

importantPoints: Application layer is closest to the end user
Provides interface between applications and network
DNS top-level domain is the last part (.com, .org, .edu)
DNS hierarchy: root → TLD → authoritative name servers
Local DNS servers can map internal hosts and forward external queries
DHCP automates IP address management on large networks
Home routers typically act as DHCP servers for local devices
HTTP GET retrieves data from web servers
HTTP POST sends data to web servers
HTTPS uses SSL/TLS encryption for security
SMTP is used to SEND email
POP3 downloads email (typically removes from server)
IMAP keeps email on server (syncs across devices)
FTP supports both upload (PUT) and download (GET)
FTP uses two TCP connections: control and data
SMB (Server Message Block) provides file/print sharing in Windows
Application layer protocols: HTTP, DNS, DHCP, FTP, SMTP, POP3, IMAP, SMB
Client initiates requests; server provides services
